truth: For natural gas distribution, a facility, which is the collection of all distribution pipelines, metering stations, and regulating stations that are operated by an LDC, is required to do at least one facility wide leak detection survey per calendar year and has the option to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys; if the facility selects this option, the additional facility-wide survey(s) must be completed during the same calendar year in order to account for fixing one or more leaks in the annual GHG report.  If the facility chooses to fix one or more leaks and conduct another survey to determine that the component is not leaking, it must conduct a facility wide leak detection survey in order to account for fixing the leak(s) in the annual GHG report.  As leaks are random in nature and while some leaks are fixed others are likely to occur.  Therefore, a comprehensive survey is the only statistically relevant manner by which to establish facility-wide leak emissions rates and account for leaks repaired.  Please see the response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1014-9 (Response to Comments, pp. 1281-1282, http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf) for further details.  It is very important to note that the requirement to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys should a company wish to account for fixing a leak does not preclude in any way a company from repairing a leak.  If a company chooses to conduct only one facility-wide leak detection survey in a calendar year but finds a leak during the survey, the company can and is encouraged to fix the leak.  The leak detected though, as noted above, must be reported as a leaker for the entire calendar year should the company choose not to conduct a second survey.

question: What happens if an LDC goes out to a custody transfer city gate station year after year and finds that it has no leaking components?  Could EPA provide a sunset provision so that annual leak surveys would no longer be required?
answer: If an LDC consistently finds no leaking components during annual surveys at a custody transfer city gate station, the EPA may consider providing a sunset provision to eliminate the requirement for annual leak surveys. The owner or operator must comply with the equipment leak survey requirements unless the above grade stations are subject to the well site or compressor station fugitive emissions standards, or a leak detection method described in § 98.234(a) is used. If the LDC wishes to discontinue annual leak surveys, they must submit a formal notification to the Administrator and demonstrate a consistent history of no leaking components over several years to support this request.

truth: Equipment/component leaks are random in nature and minimal leaks in one year do not guarantee similar leak levels in the future.  There are no sunsetting provisions for individual emissions sources, only facilities.  EPA has provided provisions that allow facilities to stop reporting under certain conditions and with prior notification to EPA.  Please see 40 CFR 98.2(i) (1) – (i) (3).  EPA addressed sunset provisions in general in the proposal to the 2009 Mandatory Reporting of Greenhouse Gases Rule (74 FR 16478).

question: Would a monitoring plan that results in 10% of stations being monitored in each of years 1 and 2, 40% in year 3, 20% in year 4 and 20% in year five, be consistent with the rule language of "approximately equal across all years in the cycle."
answer: Based on the text analysis, the content provided does not contain any relevant information related to the question about monitoring plans and station percentages. However, the table analysis indicates that the monitoring plan described, with 10% of stations being monitored in each of years 1 and 2, 40% in year 3, 20% in year 4, and 20% in year 5, is not consistent with the rule language of 'approximately equal across all years in the cycle.' The distribution of monitoring does not align with the requirement of having an approximately equal distribution across all years in the cycle.

truth: As noted in the preamble, the purpose of this provision was to reduce burden for reporters, including the option to better align survey frequencies between the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program and Department of Transportation regulations.  The statement in the preamble regarding a “minimum of 20 percent of their total number of stations being leak surveyed annually” was considered for cases where a facility chose a period of less than 5 years. We also recognize that there is a related comment and response in, “Mandatory Greenhouse Gas Reporting Rule: EPA's Response to Public Comments: “2011 Technical Revisions to the Petroleum and Natural Gas Systems Category of the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Rule” (see DCN: EPA-HQ-OAR-2011-0512-0030) where EPA may also appear to reject the 10%-10%-40%-20%-20% approach outlined above.  However, EPA understood the commenter’s recommendation as to be suggesting measurement of 10% of stations per year, over a ten year period. EPA’s objection to the comment to monitor 10% of stations per year would have been inconsistent with a five-year cycle.  Yes.   According to 98.233(q)(8)(i), “Natural gas distribution facilities may choose to conduct leak detection at T-D transfer stations over multiple years, not exceeding a five year period to cover all T-D transfer stations.  If the facility chooses to use the multiple year option, then the number of T-D transfer stations monitored in each year should be approximately equal across all years in the cycle without monitoring the same station twice during the multiple year survey.”  EPA confirms that an approach of conducting monitoring at 10% of the facilities in each of the first two years, followed by 40%, 20% and 20% in years three, four and five would be consistent with the rule language that the number of stations monitored be “approximately equal” over the number of years surveyed.

question: What types of instruments are permissible for use in detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W?
answer: The permissible instruments for detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W include Method 21, acoustic leak detection device, infrared laser beam illuminated instrument, best available monitoring methods, and population emission factors for different components and services. These instruments and methods are used to conduct leak detection surveys, calculate equipment leak emissions, and estimate methane emissions from various equipment in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, gathering, boosting, transmission, storage, and distribution facilities as specified in the regulations. Additionally, specific measurement devices such as flow meters are required to be operated continuously, and the use of appropriate default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for compressor components in gas service and non-compressor components in gas service is mandated. The regulations also specify the use of population emission factors for natural gas pneumatic device vents, concentration of GHG in produced natural gas, average estimated number of hours in the operating year the devices were operational, and annual total volumetric GHG emissions at standard conditions in standard cubic feet per year from all natural gas driven pneumatic pump venting. The instruments and methods mentioned in the regulations provide comprehensive guidance for detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W.

truth: For conducting leak detection required by subpart W, reporters have the option to use optical gas imaging instruments, infrared laser beam illuminated instruments, or acoustic leak detection devices as outlined in 40 CFR 98.234(a).  In addition, reporters may use other instruments, however those instruments must comply with the provisions as stated in 40 CFR 98.234(a)(2).

question: Can data from a state permit-required fugitive emissions monitoring program already in place, which has a lower leak detection rate of 500 ppm, be used to estimate fugitive greenhouse gas emissions under §98.233(q)?
answer: Yes, data from a state permit-required fugitive emissions monitoring program with a lower leak detection rate of 500 ppm can be used to estimate fugitive greenhouse gas emissions under §98.233(q). The default whole gas emission factors and leaker emission factors available in the provided tables can be applied to the relevant components and equipment from the monitoring program to estimate fugitive greenhouse gas emissions.

question: Does 98.233(q), "Leak detection and leaker emission factors," apply to wellheads, separators at well site, storage tanks and other equipment defined by "production equipment"?
answer: Yes, 98.233(q) applies to wellheads, separators at well site, storage tanks, and other equipment defined by 'production equipment'. The text analysis indicates that equipment integral to the extraction, processing, or movement of oil or natural gas includes these components, along with separators, compressors, and dehydrators used in production. It also mentions equipment leaks from valves, connectors, open-ended lines, and pressure relief valves associated with storage wellheads, as well as equipment leaks from tanks for the storage of water and hydrocarbon liquids. The table analysis confirms that 98.233(q) provides default whole gas emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, gathering and boosting facilities, as well as leaker emission factors for various components, including the mentioned production equipment. However, the formula analysis did not provide specific details related to the application of 'Leak detection and leaker emission factors' to the mentioned equipment. Therefore, based on the text and table analysis, it can be concluded that 98.233(q) does apply to wellheads, separators at well site, storage tanks, and other production equipment.

truth: Onshore production reporters do not need to perform leak detection under §98.233(q) for equipment leaks.  For an onshore petroleum and natural gas production facility, equipment leaks are calculated with the methodology in §98.233(r), using population count and population emissions factors.

question: In 98.236(c)(3)( i ) is the "total throughput off the acid gas removal unit" to be reported is the volume of gas exiting the AGR unit (outlet gas), not the volume of gas vented to atmosphere?
answer: In 98.236(c)(3)( i ), the 'total throughput off the acid gas removal unit' to be reported is the volume of gas exiting the AGR unit (outlet gas), not the volume of gas vented to atmosphere. This information is based on the default whole gas emission factors provided for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, as well as the default whole gas leaker emission factors for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and gathering facilities.

question: In 98.233.d.8 are we allowed to assume that volume fraction of CO2 content in natural gas out of the AGR unit is zero?
answer: Based on the text analysis, the regulations specify methods for estimating the CO2 content in natural gas flowing out of the acid gas removal (AGR) unit, such as using a continuous gas analyzer or taking quarterly gas samples. The use of default percentages or site-specific engineering estimates for greenhouse gas (GHG) mole fraction in natural gas is also allowed. Therefore, it is necessary to follow the prescribed methods and considerations to accurately determine the fraction of CO2 in the natural gas flowing out of the AGR unit. The table analysis did not provide specific information regarding the volume fraction of CO2 content in natural gas out of the AGR unit, so we cannot assume that the volume fraction of CO2 content in natural gas out of the AGR unit is zero based solely on the information provided in the tables.

truth: No.  §98.233(d)(8) does not instruct reporters to assume a volumetric fraction of zero for Vol0.  Reporters must use one of the methods specified in §98.233(d)(8) to determine the CO2 content of the natural gas exiting the AGR unit (Vol0).

question: Do acid gas removal units which are used only to sweeten a liquid stream meet the definition of acid gas removal units?
answer: Based on the provided information, acid gas removal units are designed to separate hydrogen sulfide and/or carbon dioxide from sour natural gas using liquid or solid absorbents or membrane separators. Therefore, if an acid gas removal unit is used solely to sweeten a liquid stream, it would still meet the definition of an acid gas removal unit as long as it performs the function of separating hydrogen sulfide and/or carbon dioxide from the sour natural gas, regardless of the specific application of the treated gas. However, the formula analysis suggests that units used only to sweeten a liquid stream do not meet the definition of acid gas removal units as they are specifically designed to remove acidic components such as carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulfide from natural gas and other hydrocarbon streams. The table analysis does not provide specific information regarding acid gas removal units used only for sweetening a liquid stream. Therefore, while the text analysis and formula analysis support the possibility of such units meeting the definition, the absence of specific details in the table analysis makes it difficult to conclusively determine if they meet the definition of acid gas removal units based on the provided information.

question: If all of the emissions from an AGR unit are recovered and transferred outside of the facility, does the facility still need to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then "reduce" the emission to zero?
answer: If all of the emissions from an acid gas removal (AGR) unit are recovered and transferred outside of the facility, the facility still needs to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then 'reduce' the emission to zero. This is because the calculation and reporting of emissions are necessary for regulatory and compliance purposes, regardless of whether the emissions are recovered and transferred outside of the facility. Additionally, the adjustment of CO2 emissions estimated in paragraphs (d)(1) through (d)(10) of this section downward by the magnitude of C emissions from the acid gas removal unit is a required step regardless of the fate of the recovered emissions.

truth: With regards to acid gas injection wells and subparts PP and UU, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-0582-31 in the Response to Comments (pages 1474 - 1476) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.  EPA requires reporters to calculate emissions from AGR units and then adjust them downwards by the amount transferred outside of the facility.  Therefore, if 100% of the CO2 recovered from an AGR unit is transferred outside of the facility, then CO2 emissions from the AGR unit must be calculated prior to determining the amount being transferred outside the facility.  Note that §98.236(c)(3) requires separate reporting of both the AGR emissions and emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility, even if the values are the same.
relevance_reason: The answer correctly states that the facility still needs to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then 'reduce' the emission to zero, and provides additional information on why this is necessary for regulatory and compliance purposes.
groundedness_reason: The answer logically follows from the information contained in the context. The passage clearly states that even if all emissions from an AGR unit are recovered and transferred outside the facility, the facility still needs to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then 'reduce' the emission to zero. This is because the calculation and reporting of emissions are necessary for regulatory and compliance purposes, regardless of whether the emissions are recovered and transferred outside of the facility.
dontknowness_reason: The answer completely answers the question and conveys no uncertainty.
coherence_reason: The answer is well-structured and coherent. It provides a clear and concise explanation of why the facility still needs to calculate emissions from the AGR unit and reduce them to zero, even if the emissions are recovered and transferred outside of the facility. The answer also references the relevant sections of the regulations to support its explanation.

question: Can facilities performing on-site acid gas injection estimate their emissions downward according to the provisions in 98.233(d)(11) for AGR unit emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility?
answer: Yes, facilities performing on-site acid gas injection can estimate their emissions downward according to the provisions in 98.233(d)(11) for AGR unit emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility. The specific emission factors from Table W-1A of Subpart W of Part 98 and Table W-1E can be used in the calculations based on the survey method specified in § 98.234(a)(7) for leaker components.

truth: Reporters performing on-site injection of acid gas may not adjust emissions downward. §98.233(d)(11) clearly states that you may only adjust emissions estimates downwards for emissions recovered and transferred OUTSIDE the facility.  Please see EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-0582-31 in the Response To Comments (pages 1474 - 1476) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.

question: For AGR vents is the use of a meter to measure flow rates required?
answer: Based on the regulations, the use of a meter to measure flow rates is required for AGR vents to calculate emissions for CO2. The regulations specify the measurement of volumetric flow at standard conditions using a temporary meter such as a vane anemometer or a permanent flow meter. However, the emission factors provided in the tables can be used to estimate emissions without the need for flow rate measurements using a meter. It is important to consider the annual total volumetric GHG emissions at standard conditions in standard cubic feet per year from all natural gas driven pneumatic pump venting, as well as the population emission factors for natural gas driven pneumatic pumps, and the concentration of GHGi, CH4, or CO2 in produced natural gas for accurate measurements.

question: For which units of measure are we required to calculate and report emissions using Equation W-3? May we use a flow meter to calculate annual emission CO2?
answer: Equation W-3 is required to calculate and report emissions for equipment components in onshore natural gas transmission compression, LNG storage, LNG import and export equipment, and natural gas distribution. The emission factors for these components are provided in Tables W-3A, W-4A, W-5A, W-6A, and W-7. It is not mentioned in the content whether flow meters may be used to calculate annual emission CO2. However, for the calculation of annual CO2 emissions, you may use either Equation C-1 or Equation C-2a for Tier 3 or Tier 4 methodology in subpart C of this part. The use of a flow meter to calculate annual CO2 emissions is not explicitly specified in the content.

truth: The units of measure for emissions calculated in Equation W-3 are in cubic feet per year. However, §98.233(d)(10) requires that the volumetric emissions of equation W-3 be converted into mass emissions using §98.233(v)’s methods.  You must report emissions in metric tons of CO2e to meet the reporting requirements in §98.236(c)(3)(v).  If reporters use the methodology set forth in §98.233(d)(2), then a vent flow meter must be used to determine the total annual volume of vent gas flowing out of the AGR unit.

question: For blowdown vent stacks does the 98.233.i reference to containers less than 50 cubic feet total physical volume refer to a gas volume or a physical container volume?
answer: The 98.233(i) reference to containers less than 50 cubic feet total physical volume refers to the physical container volume, not the gas volume. Therefore, it pertains to the actual physical volume of the container and not the gas volume.

truth: The unique physical volume between isolation valves should be considered against the 50 cubic feet threshold for blowdown vent stacks.  As stated in 40 CRF § 98.233(i)(2), unique physical volumes smaller than 50 cubic feet are exempt from reporting under § 98.233(i).  Please see EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1018-27 in Response to Comments (pages 1464-1465) (http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf).

question: May average blowdown volumes be used for industry segments (processing, transmission, and LNG imports-exports) where reporting of this emission source is required?
answer: The average blowdown volumes may not be used for industry segments (processing, transmission, and LNG imports-exports) where reporting of this emission source is required. The emission factors provided in the tables are specific to different equipment components and survey methods, and they are used to calculate emissions from leaking components using the specified emission factors for each component and survey method as outlined in the relevant tables. Therefore, it is essential to use the specific emission factors for accurate reporting of emissions from these industry segments. However, the text analysis result suggests that average blowdown volumes may be used for industry segments where reporting of this emission source is required. It is important to note that the formula analysis result did not provide specific details or parameters related to the emissions from industrial processes. Therefore, it is recommended to rely on the specific emission factors provided in the tables for accurate reporting of emissions from industry segments.

question: Will EPA approve the use of BAMM relating to the measurement of isolation valves at compressors in the shut down depressurized mode that are to be measured at least once every three calendar years?
answer: Based on the regulations outlined, the EPA will approve the use of BAMM for the measurement of isolation valves at compressors in the shut down depressurized mode, provided that the measurement is taken as specified in paragraph (o)(1)(i)(C) of this section at least once in any three consecutive calendar years. Additionally, the EPA provides default emission factors for various equipment components and population emission factors for different services, but specific approval for the use of BAMM relating to the measurement of isolation valves at compressors in the shut down depressurized mode that are to be measured at least once every three calendar years is not directly provided in the given information. Further clarification or specific details may be required for a more accurate analysis.

As June 30, 2013 falls on a weekend, BAMM requests for the 2014 reporting year are due by July 1, 2013.

question: Do dehydrators which are used to dry a liquid stream meet the definition of dehydrator?
answer: Yes, dehydrators used to dry a liquid stream meet the definition of dehydrator as they are designed to remove water vapor from the input stream, typically using a liquid absorbent such as desiccant or glycol to absorb the water vapor from the wet gas. The absorbed water is then removed from the absorbent, allowing the natural gas to be dried to the specified water content. Therefore, based on the provided information, dehydrators used to dry a liquid stream align with the definition of a dehydrator. Additionally, the tables contain default emission factors for various components and equipment used in onshore petroleum and natural gas production, but the specific definition of 'dehydrator' and its applicability to the provided emission factors is not explicitly mentioned. There is no specific Latex math formula provided to analyze the question further.

question: The emission methods for dehydrator vents with daily throughputs less than 0.4 MMscfd in the preamble (use flow rate of wet NG and EF) contradict the requirements in the rule (use dehydrator count and EF).
answer: The emission methods for dehydrator vents with daily throughputs less than 0.4 MMscfd in the preamble contradict the requirements in the rule. The rule specifies the use of dehydrator count and Emission Factor (EF) for calculation, whereas the preamble mentions a different approach using engineering estimates and software programs. Additionally, the emission factors provided in the tables are specific to different components and service types. However, the contradiction in the emission methods for dehydrator vents with daily throughputs less than 0.4 MMscfd can be resolved by using the appropriate emission factors from Table W-1E for leaker emission factors and Table W-1A for population emission factors. These tables provide emission factors for different components and services, which can be used to calculate emissions based on the dehydrator count and emission factors, as required by the rule.

question: Under §98.233(e)(1), emissions must be calculated from dehydrator vents with throughput greater than or equal to 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day.  Is this throughput specific to vent throughput or dehydrator throughput?
answer: The throughput requirement of 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day specified in §98.233(e)(1) is specific to the vent throughput and not the dehydrator throughput. This means that emissions must be calculated from dehydrator vents with a throughput greater than or equal to 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day. The calculation for reporting emissions from dehydrator vents is based on the vent throughput, not the dehydrator throughput.

question: For Equation W-21, Flare Emissions, Do you use "5" for Rj (number of carbon atoms) for hydrocarbons with more than 5 carbons?
answer: Yes, for Equation W-21, flare emissions, the value of Rj (number of carbon atoms) for hydrocarbons with more than 5 carbon atoms should be considered as 5. This is based on the information from text analysis, table analysis, and formula analysis, all of which confirm that a value of 5 should be used for Rj when dealing with hydrocarbons with more than 5 carbon atoms in the context of Equation W-21.

question: Are flare emissions included in the 98.2(a)(3)(iii) combined emissions from all stationary fuel combustion sources when determining applicability for Subpart W per §98.231(a)?
answer: Yes, flare emissions are included in the 98.2(a)(3)(iii) combined emissions from all stationary fuel combustion sources when determining applicability for Subpart W per §98.231(a). The methodology specified in §§ 98.253(b)(1) through (b)(3) requires the calculation of CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from flares, and these emissions are considered as part of the combined emissions from all stationary fuel combustion sources. However, it's important to note that the default whole gas leaker emission factors provided in Table W-1E to Subpart W of Part 98 do not include flare emissions. If flare emissions need to be considered, specific measurements and calculations for flare emissions would need to be performed separately.

truth: However, for the 2011 reporting year onwards, you must include flare stack emissions in the applicability determination, as flares are included under subpart W.Â  To determine facility applicability, you must determine if you meet the requirements of Â§98.2(a)(1), (a)(2) or (a)(3).Â  Based on the information provided EPA assumes you meet the definition of the source category for subpart W and are only subject to reporting for subparts C and W.

question: Emissions from flares are specifically excluded under 98.232(e) but methods for these emissions are provided in 98.233. Can you clarify which section of the rule is the correct guiding action?
answer: Emissions from flares that burn blast furnace gas or coke oven gas are specifically excluded under 98.232(e) but methods for these emissions are provided in 98.233. Therefore, the correct guiding action for the calculation of emissions from flares that burn blast furnace gas or coke oven gas is to follow the procedures and methodologies outlined in 98.233 for accurate reporting and compliance.

truth: Under §98.232(e), emissions from flare stacks are not required to be reported as a separate emission source for onshore natural gas transmission compression facilities.  However, this does not exclude the reporting of flared emissions from the other emission sources listed in §98.232(e) if they are routed to a flare.  The flare source type in §98.233(n) covers only emissions that are not reported in association with any of the other source types in §98.233; see §98.233(n)(10).  For example, if transmission storage tank emissions are going to a flare, then the rule requires the adjustment of transmission storage tank emissions sent to flare per §98.233(k)(4).  The flared transmission storage tank emissions, however, have to be reported as transmission storage tank emissions under §98.236(c)(9).

question: Does a simple open pipe with no flare tip count as a flare under 98.233 (n ) in Subpart W?
answer: Based on the combined analysis, it is clear that a simple open pipe with no flare tip does not count as a flare under 98.233(n) in Subpart W. The text analysis, table analysis, and formula analysis all support this conclusion, indicating that the emission factors and population emission factors listed in the tables are specific to various equipment components and services in onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities, but do not include specific information about a simple open pipe with no flare tip. Therefore, the consensus from the analyses is that such a pipe does not meet the criteria to be considered a flare under 98.233(n) in Subpart W.

truth: 40 CFR § 98.238 defines a flare as “…a combustion device, whether at ground level or elevated, that uses an open or closed flame to combust waste gases without energy recovery.”  An open pipe without combustion would not be considered a flare, but any hydrocarbon releases through it would be considered “vented emissions” under §98.238, which includes “process designed flow to the atmosphere through seals or vent pipes.”

question: Under Subpart W, under both the onshore production and gas processing source categories, are we required to report emissions from all flares at the gas processing facility or on or associated with a well pad, including emergency flares?
answer: Based on the text analysis, the specific requirement for reporting emissions from all flares at the gas processing facility or associated with a well pad, including emergency flares, is not explicitly mentioned in the provided content. However, the reporting requirements for emissions from gas processing facilities and well pads are detailed in subpart W of the regulations. Therefore, the reporting of emissions from all flares, including emergency flares, should be determined based on the specific guidelines and definitions provided in subpart W of the regulations. Additionally, the table analysis indicates that under Subpart W, for both the onshore production and gas processing source categories, emissions from all flares at the gas processing facility or on or associated with a well pad, including emergency flares, are required to be reported. This information is based on the default emission factors and population emission factors provided in the tables for different equipment components and services. It is important to note that these default emission factors are to be used if the facility does not have direct measurements and follows the specified survey methods for estimation. However, the formula analysis does not directly relate to the question about reporting emissions from flares at gas processing facilities. Therefore, it is recommended to review the specific regulations and guidelines under Subpart W to determine the exact requirements for reporting emissions from flares at gas processing facilities.

truth: Yes, emergency flares are covered under the general category of flares.  For reporting purposes, in the final rule, EPA reduced the burden associated with the flare monitoring and reporting requirements by allowing the use of engineering calculations based on process knowledge, company records, and best available data for estimating flow volumes and gas compositions.
